isis.stitle: Spanish - Guía para Localización de Fallas del Sistema Eléctrico - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - Meritor Medium Duty Front Drive Steer Axle - Prepare Parts for Assembly - Inspect Parts

svcproc.title: Inspect Parts
svcproc.para: It is very important to inspect all parts carefully and completely before the axle is assembled. Check all parts for wear or stress and replace damaged parts. Replacement of damaged parts can prevent complete failure of the assembly.

step1.para: Inspect the cup, cone, rollers and cage of all tapered roller bearings in the assembly. If any of the following conditions exist, the bearing MUST be replaced (Figure 29).

figure.caption: Figure 29. Inspect Cup, Cone, Rollers and Cage

step2.para: The center of large diameter end of rollers worn level with or below the outer surface.
The radius at large diameter end of rollers worn to sharp edge.
A visible roller groove in the cup or cone inner race surfaces. The groove can be seen at the small or large diameter end of both parts.
Deep cracks or breaks in the cup, cone inner race or roller surfaces (Figure 30).
Bright wear marks on the outer surface of the roller cage (Figure 31).
Damage on rollers and on surfaces of the cup and cone inner race that touch the rollers (Figure 32).
Damage on the cup and cone inner race surfaces that touch the rollers (Figure 33).
Remove all dirt from housing sleeves.
Check for cracks, loose studs and damage to machined surfaces. Repair or replace damaged parts.
Check king pin bushing for wear or damage.

step1.para: Inspect axle shafts for wear, stress and cracks at the splines, shaft and yoke ears.

step2.para: Inspect axle shaft bushings (one in housing, one in spindle) for damage.
Inspect axle shaft oil seals (one in housing, one in spindle) for damage.

step1.para: Inspect needle roller thrust bearing for wear or damage.
Inspect the knuckle or steering stops for wear or damage.

caution.para: You must inspect the tie rod ends when you service the axle.

note.para: Do NOT repair tie rod ends. Damaged tie rod ends MUST be replaced.

step2.para: Check seals for damage. Check that seals are correctly fastened on socket. If tie rod ends have grease fittings, replace damaged seals.
If a grease fitting is missing, install a new one. Do not attempt to install a fitting if the tie rod end is a non-greaseable design (Figure 34).
Tighten all grease fittings to the specified torque. Refer to Fastener Torque Chart.

caution.para: Do not overtighten fitting or thread damage may occur.

step1.para: Inspect axle housing knuckle socket bushings for wear.
Inspect inner and outer axle shaft bushings for wear.
Inspect steering arm and ball joint for damage/wear.
Inspect axle housing for cracks and leaks.
